Project.Abstract: The resettlement of the population in rural Turkey and the production of a new settlement structure has been a recurrent theme in the grand narrative of Turkish modernization. The Turkish modernizers considered a Turkish cultural identity the foundation of social life and seriously thought that they could produce ?Turks? by creating appropriate environments for the constitution of social life. It has been argued that resettlement and settlement policies did not only have a productive side ? the making of a new environment for the enhancement of social life and the molding of identity, but also a destructive side. This destructive side of settlement policy is situated in the definition of a ?negative?, those places and peoples who were located outside the project of modernization, and which became objects of destruction and transformation. The ?negative villages? of Abdullah Ziya in the 1930s, the hamlets (perceived as fortresses of backwardness) in the 1960s and 1970s, and the small rural settlements (conceived as insurgent-habitats) in the 1990s, were such environments to be destroyed. Their populations were to be settled in environments where state-authorities could establish a hold on them and turn them into objects of identity producing policies. The immediate concern of this thesis was an investigation into the logics of official resettlement policies in those areas where State authority was contested and challenged by the Kurdistan Workers Party PKK in the 1980s and 1990s. But the analysis of contemporary settlement policies in the southeast was combined with a genealogical approach. In this thesis genealogy was simply used to refer to the study of ancestry and familiarity between contemporary and pervious settlement policies Turkey (and did not refer to method of Foucault to establish a historical knowledge of struggles by studying dissenting opinions and theories, and local beliefs). Concretely, by means of the genealogical approach applied in this study, the evacuation and burning of villages by Turkish military, and plans of civil authorities for the design of a new settlement structure, were integrated in a histiography of settlement policies in Turkey. Three main sets of conclusions are to be drawn from the findings in this thesis, which I will summarize. 1. The evacuation of thousands of villages and the displacement of hundreds of thousands or even millions of Kurds should be viewed not as collateral damage from a war of state forces against insurgents, but as one of its very objectives. After 1991, the evacuation of villages became a constituent element of the Turkish counter-insurgency strategy against the guerrilla of the PKK. Its objective was to deprive the insurgents from their rural environment and to create a new social order based on an urban settlement structure. The objective of the resettlement policy of the Turkish army was the massive destruction of relatively small (and isolated) rural settlements, and enforced mass-migration of people from the countryside to the cities. The genealogy of settlement policies in Turkey disclosed that the dissolution of small rural settlements (although executed by means of intensive violence) was conform previous settlement policies and plans. However, the forced settlement of the displaced in large cities (within and outside the region) is at odds with previously prevailing rural settlement policies, which aimed at the establishment of growth-poles at the countryside, and, instead of accelerating migration from the countryside to the cities, had the objective of slowing down or even reversing this population movement. Historically, rural settlement policies in Turkey emanate from a radical critique on the spatial and economic dimensions of modernity. The detachment of industrialization from the rural economy and its establishment in urban centers was considered a historical error. Settlement policies aimed at the development of a new entity that is rural and urban, agricultural and industrial, and provide the basis for social life. This new entity is referred to with such different names as rurban, agrindus (tarsan), village-town, agricultural town, and center-village. Today, the conception to develop such a new settlement entity (in between the city and the village) is contested and rejected by State institutions responsible for providing security (in particular the military and governors, but to a certain extent also district officers). 2. Official plans (of civilian origin) for organizing a ?return to village? are not concerned with a recovery of the evacuated and destroyed rural settlements, but with a search for an optimal new settlement structure. Key-concepts as village-town (köy-kent), sub-region (alt-bölge) and center-village (merkez-köy) were used to probe into the possibilities of identifying rural areas where urban growth and expansion is feasible. The genealogy of settlement policies revealed that these concepts emanate from the idea that instead of massive migration from rural to urban areas, a new type of urbanization was envisaged, based on ?rural-urbanization?, the development of villages possessing urban and industrial elements. The military supported this policy until the 1980s. However, the military started to oppose these policies only a decade later, because they were thought to contribute to a partial recovery of an environment for insurgency. 3. The concept of return is insisted upon by civil society organizations to assert against the State the right of displaced villagers ? who were evacuated by brutal force and illegal means ? to return to their homes and land. Sociologically, the concept of ?village return? is problematic. Empirical evidence from this thesis indicates that not all migration from urban entities to evacuated rural entities is return. Also, the migration from urban to rural entities does not necessarily result in a recovery, but leads to the emergence of new settlement patterns and structures. Statistics of doubtful provenance suggest that villagers headed back to their homes in large numbers. These numbers need to be considered with care, since they lack detail and are not verifiable. Yet, also verifiable statistics indicating towards significant return need explanation. For example, evidence suggesting that in the province of Diyarbakir return took place to about 30 percent of the evacuated and burned villages, involving about 30 percent of the evacuated households, needs to be contextualized. Important to note is that also in cases people are allowed to construct shelters, the reconstruction of livelihood is seriously hampered, for example by the prohibition to take animals to summer pastures, which is a serious obstacle for the recovery of animal husbandry, and alternative sources of income (apart from participation in the village-guard system) not provided. The authorities do not take the responsibility to provide the returnees with basic services, for example electricity and drinking water, and returnees have to take care themselves for connection on the electricity grid and water mains. The reconstruction and equipment of schools is obstructed (with the effect that families with schoolchildren stay in the cities and do not return, except for holiday periods). Moreover, young men are fearful for paramilitaries and soldiers (and therefore do not return or only stay for short periods of time). As a consequence of several reasons, most people do not return permanently, but only seasonal or part-time, and most of the permanent returnees turn out to be elderly people.
